     }
 
     override val intrinsicSize: Size
-        get() = when {
-            // Only return a finite size if the drawable has an intrinsic size
-            drawable.intrinsicWidth >= 0 && drawable.intrinsicHeight >= 0 -> {
-                Size(
-                    width = drawable.intrinsicWidth.toFloat(),
-                    height = drawable.intrinsicHeight.toFloat(),
-                )
-            }
-            else -> Size.Unspecified
+        get() {
+            // Reading this ensures that we re-layout when invalidateDrawable() is called
+            layoutTick

> seems like everytime the size of the drawable changes we get the callback

Not quite. `invalidateDrawable()` will only be called when the drawable itself requests that it needs to be invalidated. It won't be called if Compose triggers the draw pass.

The current code is the right place, as it will update the size on any Compose draw pass. Moving it to `invalidateDrawable` will mean that it only updates the size if the drawable requests it (which may never happen) for static drawables.", 'created_at': '2022-04-21T10:01:10Z', {'push_id': 9266998128, 'size': 1, 'distinct_size': 1, 'ref': 'refs/heads/cb/snapshots-pt2', 'head': 'c021cacf8246efa5ea885cb4e0a5682e73168033', 'before': 'bbf960b6328bc8d6dee308a052be2ef283353eb2', 'commits': [{'sha': 'c021cacf8246efa5ea885cb4e0a5682e73168033', 'author': {'email': 'cbanes@twitter.com', 'name': 'Chris Banes'}, 'message': "Use layoutlib SNAPSHOTs part 2

Follow on from #377

I just realised that I didn't update the plugin or library
to actually use the SNAPSHOT versions. This PR does
that my tweaking the layoutlib version which is dynamically
added as a dependency.

I also removed hardcoded FQN references to the layoutlib
in :paparazzi. Using `project` dependencies means that
it automatically uses the correct layoutlib version,
and doesn't require the SNAPSHOTs to already be pre-pushed to

False, 'assignee': None, 'assignees': [], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 7, 'created_at': '2022-02-13T20:25:44Z', 'updated_at': '2022-02-23T14:41:49Z', 'closed_at': '2022-02-13T20:38:18Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "We have horizontally scrollable container/content. It contains about 1 to 3 (at most) containers. The design requires to have the boxes the same height, so we use intrinsic height sizing (and of course, the width is also the same). Using intrinsic is forbidden in LazyRow, so we are currently using normal scrollable Row. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/284263/153773277-158f3951-04e5-45b5-a543-197e91db1e9d.png)

It could be probably done via custom SnapperLayoutInfo, yet it seems like enormous and non trivial work/amount of code.

Do you have any idea how to make it easier?

**Solution I'd like**
I am not much sure, maybe something like this?
```kotlin
val state = rememberScrollState()
val flingBehavior = rememberSnapperFlingBehavior(state, itemWidth = 200.dp)
Row(
    Modifier
        .horizontalScroll(
            state = state,
            flingBehavior = flingBehavior,
        )
)
```

**Alternatives I've considered**

- having custom snapping code (what we have now)
- implementing SnapperLayoutInfo

'https://api.github.com/repos/chrisbanes/snapper/labels/enhancement', 'name': 'enhancement', 'color': 'a2eeef', 'default': True, 'description': 'New feature or request'}], 'state': 'closed', 'locked': False, 'assignee': None, 'assignees': [], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 4, 'created_at': '2022-02-13T20:25:44Z', 'updated_at': '2022-02-14T09:17:20Z', 'closed_at': '2022-02-13T20:38:18Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "We have horizontally scrollable container/content. It contains about 1 to 3 (at most) containers. The design requires to have the boxes the same height, so we use intrinsic height sizing (and of course, the width is also the same). Using intrinsic is forbidden in LazyRow, so we are currently using normal scrollable Row. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/284263/153773277-158f3951-04e5-45b5-a543-197e91db1e9d.png)

It could be probably done via custom SnapperLayoutInfo, yet it seems like enormous and non trivial work/amount of code.

Do you have any idea how to make it easier?

**Solution I'd like**
I am not much sure, maybe something like this?
```kotlin
val state = rememberScrollState()
val flingBehavior = rememberSnapperFlingBehavior(state, itemWidth = 200.dp)
Row(
    Modifier
        .horizontalScroll(
            state = state,
            flingBehavior = flingBehavior,
        )
)
```

**Alternatives I've considered**

- having custom snapping code (what we have now)
- implementing SnapperLayoutInfo

False, 'assignee': None, 'assignees': [], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 2, 'created_at': '2022-02-13T20:25:44Z', 'updated_at': '2022-02-13T20:38:31Z', 'closed_at': '2022-02-13T20:38:18Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "We have horizontally scrollable container/content. It contains about 1 to 3 (at most) containers. The design requires to have the boxes the same height, so we use intrinsic height sizing (and of course, the width is also the same). Using intrinsic is forbidden in LazyRow, so we are currently using normal scrollable Row. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/284263/153773277-158f3951-04e5-45b5-a543-197e91db1e9d.png)

It could be probably done via custom SnapperLayoutInfo, yet it seems like enormous and non trivial work/amount of code.

Do you have any idea how to make it easier?

**Solution I'd like**
I am not much sure, maybe something like this?
```kotlin
val state = rememberScrollState()
val flingBehavior = rememberSnapperFlingBehavior(state, itemWidth = 200.dp)
Row(
    Modifier
        .horizontalScroll(
            state = state,
            flingBehavior = flingBehavior,
        )
)
```

**Alternatives I've considered**

- having custom snapping code (what we have now)
- implementing SnapperLayoutInfo

{'push_id': 9083439991, 'size': 213, 'distinct_size': 23, 'ref': 'refs/heads/main', 'head': '4c9099ebb0cd0a2f08bd15e3ece0197ca842c7af', 'before': '79f1489cbb608ddad3ba6bfdf281694ca47befb2', 'commits': [{'sha': 'b11c87950fc9cc079608d35c8f51054775dd5568', 'author': {'email': 'chris@banes.me', 'name': 'Chris Banes'}, 'message': '[Pager] Stop consuming nested flings in cross-axis

Currently Pager consumes nested scrolls and flings in
all directions. This PR changes that so that it only
consumes nested scrolls in the main scrolling axis.

{'push_id': 9074077432, 'size': 1, 'distinct_size': 0, 'ref': 'refs/heads/snapshot', 'head': '4d27add4b2ce3e7ba6eceebb47084f43343d1cb3', 'before': '6bfa7eafb470948c7d1104c47acddbeaf99fa078', 'commits': [{'sha': '4d27add4b2ce3e7ba6eceebb47084f43343d1cb3', 'author': {'email': 'chrisbanes@users.noreply.github.com', 'name': 'Chris Banes'}, 'message': 'Add `snapIndex` lambda parameter (#15)

* Add `snapIndex` lambda parameter

This block which returns the index which the apps wishes to snap to.
The block is provided with the SnapperLayoutInfo and the index which Snapper
has determined is the correct target index. Callers can override this value as
they see fit.

A common use case could be rounding up/down to achieve groupings of items, which was
the intention of #12

* Add test for snapIndex

* Improve kdoc

* Expand snapIndex test

* Add snapIndex scenario with opposite directions

* Make snapIndex non-nullable

* Split out maximumFlingDistance to a deprecated overload

Had to remove the default value to avoid overload ambiguity.

* Re-add default value for maximumFlingDistance

This maintains binary compatibility.

* Remove extra comment

* Add `startIndex` to SnapIndex

Also added some docs for the new parameter', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/chrisbanes/snapper/commits/4d27add4b2ce3e7ba6eceebb47084f43343d1cb3'}]}

The block is provided with the SnapperLayoutInfo and the index which Snapper has determined is the correct target index. Callers can override this value as they see fit.

A common use case could be rounding up/down to achieve groupings of items, which was the intention of #12.

A very simple version could look this this:

``` kotlin
val GroupSize = 3

flingBehavior = rememberSnapperFlingBehavior(
    lazyListState = lazyListState,
    snapIndex = { layout, targetIndex ->
        val mod = targetIndex % GroupSize
        if (mod > (GroupSize / 2)) {
            // Round up towards infinity
            GroupSize + targetIndex - mod
        } else {
            // Round down towards zero
            targetIndex - mod
        }
    }
),
```

You could also look at the `layout.currentItem` to determine the fling direction to influence which direction to round.', 'created_at': '2022-02-05T14:11:14Z', 'updated_at': '2022-02-11T13:34:48Z', (#15)', 'commit_message': '* Add `snapIndex` lambda parameter

This block which returns the index which the apps wishes to snap to.
The block is provided with the SnapperLayoutInfo and the index which Snapper
has determined is the correct target index. Callers can override this value as
they see fit.

A common use case could be rounding up/down to achieve groupings of items, which was
the intention of #12

* Add test for snapIndex

* Improve kdoc

* Expand snapIndex test

* Add snapIndex scenario with opposite directions

* Make snapIndex non-nullable

* Split out maximumFlingDistance to a deprecated overload

Had to remove the default value to avoid overload ambiguity.

* Re-add default value for maximumFlingDistance

This maintains binary compatibility.

* Remove extra comment

* Add `startIndex` to SnapIndex

Also added some docs for the new parameter'}, 'active_lock_reason': None, 'merged': True, 'mergeable': None, 'rebaseable': None, 'mergeable_state': 'unknown', 'merged_by': {'login': 'chrisbanes', 'id': 227486, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjIyNzQ4Ng==', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/227486?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/chrisbanes', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/chrisbanes', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/chrisbanes/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/chrisbanes/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/chrisbanes/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/chrisbanes/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/chrisbanes/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/chrisbanes/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/chrisbanes/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/chrisbanes/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/chrisbanes/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'comments': 3, 'review_comments': 21, 'maintainer_can_modify': False, 'commits': 10, 'additions': 373, 'deletions': 103, 'changed_files': 11}}

'body': 'This block which returns the index which the apps wishes to snap to. The block is provided with the SnapperLayoutInfo and the index which Snapper has determined is the correct target index. Callers can override this value as they see fit.

A common use case could be rounding up/down to achieve groupings of items, which was the intention of #12.

A very simple version could look this this:

``` kotlin
val GroupSize = 3

flingBehavior = rememberSnapperFlingBehavior(
    lazyListState = lazyListState,
    snapIndex = { layout, targetIndex ->
        val mod = targetIndex % GroupSize
        if (mod > (GroupSize / 2)) {
            // Round up towards infinity
            GroupSize + targetIndex - mod
        } else {
            // Round down towards zero
            targetIndex - mod
        }
    }
),
```

You could also look at the `layout.currentItem` to determine the fling direction to influence which direction to round.', 'created_at': '2022-02-05T14:11:14Z', 'updated_at': '2022-02-11T12:11:41Z', 'body': 'This block which returns the index which the apps wishes to snap to. The block is provided with the SnapperLayoutInfo and the index which Snapper has determined is the correct target index. Callers can override this value as they see fit.

A common use case could be rounding up/down to achieve groupings of items, which was the intention of #12.

A very simple version could look this this:

``` kotlin
val GroupSize = 3

flingBehavior = rememberSnapperFlingBehavior(
    lazyListState = lazyListState,
    snapIndex = { layout, targetIndex ->
        val mod = targetIndex % GroupSize
        if (mod > (GroupSize / 2)) {
            // Round up towards infinity
            GroupSize + targetIndex - mod
        } else {
            // Round down towards zero
            targetIndex - mod
        }
    }
),
```

You could also look at the `layout.currentItem` to determine the fling direction to influence which direction to round.', 'created_at': '2022-02-05T14:11:14Z', 'updated_at': '2022-02-11T12:02:34Z', {'push_id': 9073289661, 'size': 12, 'distinct_size': 8, 'ref': 'refs/heads/cb/snapindex-lambda', 'head': 'd3b5a060bc80ad3ef5776a42a434fa3235d6a224', 'before': '6901db2311c3294988408392f76437ee047c47fa', 'commits': [{'sha': '1057124d53754aa7ae8d67e456bc8013c70c7c9b', 'author': {'email': 'chris@banes.me', 'name': 'Chris Banes'}, 'message': 'Fix float inaccuracies at high values

When determining the target index to fling to, we are currently
including the current index into a float.

This means that if the current scroll index is a large number (millions),
the accuracy of the decimals below that is greatly impacted, enough so to
affect rounding and the calculated scroll index.

This PR fixes that in 2 ways. First, we use double calculations for determining
the index offset. Secondly, we keep the current index out of the double.

Fixes #13', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/chrisbanes/snapper/commits/1057124d53754aa7ae8d67e456bc8013c70c7c9b'}, {'sha': '72c64f2f0d28c3c971be49c9c9c4f2112dba5c34', 'author': {'email': 'chris@banes.me', 'name': 'Chris Banes'}, 'message': 'Reduce number of CI emulator targets

and just increase energy consumption, etc.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/chrisbanes/snapper/commits/72c64f2f0d28c3c971be49c9c9c4f2112dba5c34'}, {'sha': 'a60bfd8b0b84672bf50dff81292e30dd8f4f543d', 'author': {'email': 'chris@banes.me', 'name': 'Chris Banes'}, 'message': 'Update dependencies

'body': 'This block which returns the index which the apps wishes to snap to. The block is provided with the SnapperLayoutInfo and the index which Snapper has determined is the correct target index. Callers can override this value as they see fit.

A common use case could be rounding up/down to achieve groupings of items, which was the intention of #12.

A very simple version could look this this:

``` kotlin
val GroupSize = 3

flingBehavior = rememberSnapperFlingBehavior(
    lazyListState = lazyListState,
    snapIndex = { layout, targetIndex ->
        val mod = targetIndex % GroupSize
        if (mod > (GroupSize / 2)) {
            // Round up towards infinity
            GroupSize + targetIndex - mod
        } else {
            // Round down towards zero
            targetIndex - mod
        }
    }
),
```

> It looks, like I can't solve it without additional param in snapIndex.
> Could you, please, advice something?

We don't supply the offset on purpose, because we don't know what it will be (the items won't be laid out). 'body': 'This block which returns the index which the apps wishes to snap to. The block is provided with the SnapperLayoutInfo and the index which Snapper has determined is the correct target index. Callers can override this value as they see fit.

A common use case could be rounding up/down to achieve groupings of items, which was the intention of #12.

A very simple version could look this this:

``` kotlin
val GroupSize = 3

flingBehavior = rememberSnapperFlingBehavior(
    lazyListState = lazyListState,
    snapIndex = { layout, targetIndex ->
        val mod = targetIndex % GroupSize
        if (mod > (GroupSize / 2)) {
            // Round up towards infinity
            GroupSize + targetIndex - mod
        } else {
            // Round down towards zero
            targetIndex - mod
        }
    }
),
```

You could also look at the `layout.currentItem` to determine the fling direction to influence which direction to round.', 'created_at': '2022-02-05T14:11:14Z', 'updated_at': '2022-02-10T09:59:13Z', 'body': 'This block which returns the index which the apps wishes to snap to. The block is provided with the SnapperLayoutInfo and the index which Snapper has determined is the correct target index. Callers can override this value as they see fit.

A common use case could be rounding up/down to achieve groupings of items, which was the intention of #12.

A very simple version could look this this:

``` kotlin
val GroupSize = 3

flingBehavior = rememberSnapperFlingBehavior(
    lazyListState = lazyListState,
    snapIndex = { layout, targetIndex ->
        val mod = targetIndex % GroupSize
        if (mod > (GroupSize / 2)) {
            // Round up towards infinity
            GroupSize + targetIndex - mod
        } else {
            // Round down towards zero
            targetIndex - mod
        }
    }
),
```

You could also look at the `layout.currentItem` to determine the fling direction to influence which direction to round.', 'created_at': '2022-02-05T14:11:14Z', 'updated_at': '2022-02-09T18:06:14Z', {'push_id': 9038376789, 'size': 2, 'distinct_size': 0, 'ref': 'refs/heads/snapshot', 'head': '72c64f2f0d28c3c971be49c9c9c4f2112dba5c34', 'before': '5ce2d38b741db69d051bf7927498956cd9c04770', 'commits': [{'sha': '1057124d53754aa7ae8d67e456bc8013c70c7c9b', 'author': {'email': 'chris@banes.me', 'name': 'Chris Banes'}, 'message': 'Fix float inaccuracies at high values

When determining the target index to fling to, we are currently
including the current index into a float.

This means that if the current scroll index is a large number (millions),
the accuracy of the decimals below that is greatly impacted, enough so to
affect rounding and the calculated scroll index.

This PR fixes that in 2 ways. First, we use double calculations for determining
the index offset. Secondly, we keep the current index out of the double.

Fixes #13', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/chrisbanes/snapper/commits/1057124d53754aa7ae8d67e456bc8013c70c7c9b'}, {'sha': '72c64f2f0d28c3c971be49c9c9c4f2112dba5c34', 'author': {'email': 'chris@banes.me', 'name': 'Chris Banes'}, 'message': 'Reduce number of CI emulator targets

They add little coverage over 26, 29 & Robolectric,
and just increase energy consumption, etc.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/chrisbanes/snapper/commits/72c64f2f0d28c3c971be49c9c9c4f2112dba5c34'}]}

{'push_id': 9038374735, 'size': 2, 'distinct_size': 2, 'ref': 'refs/heads/main', 'head': '72c64f2f0d28c3c971be49c9c9c4f2112dba5c34', 'before': '5ce2d38b741db69d051bf7927498956cd9c04770', 'commits': [{'sha': '1057124d53754aa7ae8d67e456bc8013c70c7c9b', 'author': {'email': 'chris@banes.me', 'name': 'Chris Banes'}, 'message': 'Fix float inaccuracies at high values

When determining the target index to fling to, we are currently
including the current index into a float.

This means that if the current scroll index is a large number (millions),
the accuracy of the decimals below that is greatly impacted, enough so to
affect rounding and the calculated scroll index.

This PR fixes that in 2 ways. First, we use double calculations for determining
the index offset. Secondly, we keep the current index out of the double.

Fixes #13', 'distinct': True, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/chrisbanes/snapper/commits/1057124d53754aa7ae8d67e456bc8013c70c7c9b'}, {'sha': '72c64f2f0d28c3c971be49c9c9c4f2112dba5c34', 'author': {'email': 'chris@banes.me', 'name': 'Chris Banes'}, 'message': 'Reduce number of CI emulator targets

They add little coverage over 26, 29 & Robolectric,
and just increase energy consumption, etc.', 'distinct': True, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/chrisbanes/snapper/commits/72c64f2f0d28c3c971be49c9c9c4f2112dba5c34'}]}

{'push_id': 9019019822, 'size': 1, 'distinct_size': 1, 'ref': 'refs/heads/cb/fling-large-index', 'head': '522b7b4f5f876b3e417240e2fe378710ca6b339f', 'before': 'aaab2bdaf3716cd095ccd1b06683a55601344b67', 'commits': [{'sha': '522b7b4f5f876b3e417240e2fe378710ca6b339f', 'author': {'email': 'chris@banes.me', 'name': 'Chris Banes'}, 'message': 'Fix float inaccuracies at high values

When determining the target index to fling to, we are currently
including the current index into a float.

This means that if the current scroll index is a large number (millions),
the accuracy of the decimals below that is greatly impacted, enough so to
affect rounding and the calculated scroll index.

This PR fixes that in 2 ways. First, we use double calculations for determining
the index offset. Secondly, we keep the current index out of the double.

Fixes #13', 'distinct': True, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/chrisbanes/snapper/commits/522b7b4f5f876b3e417240e2fe378710ca6b339f'}]}

{'push_id': 8938817517, 'size': 1, 'distinct_size': 0, 'ref': 'refs/heads/snapshot', 'head': '1fe2edcfa0f7db2683e8377db83ccd99253d95cb', 'before': 'e2525c144aa44536b5700b05e7f03b6d58bc4f48', 'commits': [{'sha': '1fe2edcfa0f7db2683e8377db83ccd99253d95cb', 'author': {'email': 'chrisbanes@users.noreply.github.com', 'name': 'Chris Banes'}, 'message': "Tidy up target index calculation (#10)

* Tidy up target index calculation

This commit updates determineTargetIndex() to be more consistent
with other implementations.

The new implementation is roughly the same as before, but hopefully
clearer to understand. The changes mean that we can now use a round,
rather than a truncate. This which means that flings which travel
most of the distance will now target the 'next' page. Previously they
would truncate down towards 0.

* Add test parameters to test similar to Accompanist Pager", 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/chrisbanes/snapper/commits/1fe2edcfa0f7db2683e8377db83ccd99253d95cb'}]}

{'push_id': 8938816027, 'size': 1, 'distinct_size': 1, 'ref': 'refs/heads/main', 'head': '1fe2edcfa0f7db2683e8377db83ccd99253d95cb', 'before': 'e2525c144aa44536b5700b05e7f03b6d58bc4f48', 'commits': [{'sha': '1fe2edcfa0f7db2683e8377db83ccd99253d95cb', 'author': {'email': 'chrisbanes@users.noreply.github.com', 'name': 'Chris Banes'}, 'message': "Tidy up target index calculation (#10)

* Tidy up target index calculation

This commit updates determineTargetIndex() to be more consistent
with other implementations.

The new implementation is roughly the same as before, but hopefully
clearer to understand. The changes mean that we can now use a round,
rather than a truncate. This which means that flings which travel
most of the distance will now target the 'next' page. Previously they
would truncate down towards 0.

* Add test parameters to test similar to Accompanist Pager", 'distinct': True, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/chrisbanes/snapper/commits/1fe2edcfa0f7db2683e8377db83ccd99253d95cb'}]}

(#10)', 'commit_message': "* Tidy up target index calculation

This commit updates determineTargetIndex() to be more consistent
with other implementations.

The new implementation is roughly the same as before, but hopefully
clearer to understand. The changes mean that we can now use a round,
rather than a truncate. This which means that flings which travel
most of the distance will now target the 'next' page. Previously they
would truncate down towards 0.
